description.text:
This is a printable front wheel for I-robot Roomba 700 series, it may fit others but I can't guarantee it. The wheel uses two 4mm x 13mm x 5mm bearings and re-uses the original axle. I printed mine in ABS using pillar supports for the bearing indent. It hasn't finished printing yet but I will probably have to heat the part and the bearing a bit then hammer them together as I am expecting a tight fit.
I figured using bearings would help with the fact the part no longer has a soft tread and would roll better and last longer this way.
As I have not tried it out yet I have no clue if it will work...I will update when it finishes printing.

comments.text: This is a great model but I'm finding that the slits are lining up correctly. Also it came out a bit too wide on my printer. I made some adjustments. Also, for the best strength, print this on its side with support or else its easy to break the end off if your part doesn't fit loosely within the enclosure. My first print was a bit off due to not lining up with the screw posts and it being a bit wide so it was a tight fit and when trying to pull it apart the end snapped right off. Print in PETG on its side and this part should last forever. I'm using this for my Samsung Galaxy Tab 4.

comments.text: No problem. I can't say whether or not 3DR will make the app any better in regards to the format screen size but if any company would go the extra step to improve it later on, it would be 3DR. Likewise, I don't find it that bothersome but if it bothers you that much I would say just get the mini. The only reason I have an air 2,or an iPad at all for that matter, is for my flight training. Android has the added benefit of having the Tower app if you would ever be interested in flying missioned flights. If you go the android route I suggest getting a Nexus tablet or Galaxy tablet as they are much cheaper than an iPad.

description.text:
I like to break toothpicks in half and carry them in my pocket. The problem is that they stab me. I made this little box for my pocket, not too big, slightly rounded corners. It will hold 3 or 4 toothpicks that are broken in half. perfect for me. The box started out 40 x 20 x 6 before I added the curves. Coincidentally, this little box is a perfect fit for the tiny pocket on Levi's 501 jeans.
  • I revised my little box - I made it a little bit taller so pills will fit inside now.
    pocket_box_taller
    • I printed it in abs for strength. If it lifts a corner, who cares? It will fit better in my pocket!

description.text: UPDATE 20JAN2014: I believe I have fixed the power plug issue by just removing the parts around the micro USB input, so I hope that helps some. Also added Top and Bottom parts separatley for anyone with small platform or wants to just print a new top. The latest files are dated with "20JAN2014" in the .stl file name. OctoPrint - http://OctoPrint.org - deserved it's own Raspberry Pi case, so I made one. It will be the default case for all OctoPrint installations we do from now on. It's a derivative of the RichRap and Foosel edition of this case, and it's also on TinkerCAD for you to play with, find the link below. It will be used for The BotBQ - http://BotBQ.org - as soon as it's done printing, and I will post some pics of it as well. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/doyxhn05dAQ

UPDATE 20JAN2014: I believe I have fixed the power plug issue by just removing the parts around the micro USB input, so I hope that helps some. Also added Top and Bottom parts separatley for anyone with small platform or wants to just print a new top. The latest files are dated with "20JAN2014" in the .stl file name.  
Just print as normal... DO NOT USE A RAFT!!!!  If you want you can just use a lot of skirts and you should be fine.

I was asked to upload the models I used for my dual extrusion version of the DOOM gaming logo design by misterschultz.   I used 3D Builder to split the model so that it is now two models which you can use dual extrusion with a 3D printer with a dual extruder instead of pausing and switching out filaments for the two colors.   I imported both models into Simplify 3D however, for some reason the x,y,z offset positions come out wrong for the top model when first importing into Simplify 3D and I can't figure out why, but if you click "Reset Positions" under Change Position it will align perfectly with the bottom model right on top of it where it needs to be as it resets all the offsets to 0.   I am new to 3D modeling software and this is my very first time editing an existing model.

This hangs on the side of a wire rack shelf.  Our shelf height was 0.981 inches from the top of the top wire to the bottom of the bottom wire, so center-to-center was right at 0.8 inches.  The smaller of these, #1, was able to hold a heavy school backpack, but flexed quite a bit.  The thicker one flexed much less, though it isn't a replacement for a metal hook.
The thinner hook is 0.25 inches thick and 0.25 inches wide (from flat side to flat side).  The inside radius of the hook end is 0.375 inches.
The thicker hook is 0.375 inches thick and 0.313 inches wide.  The inside radius of the hook end is 0.5 inches.

title: Dynamic Marker and Eraser tool for industrial robot

description.text: This industrial robot tool uses an assembly of printed parts, springs and a common marker to paint on any surface with the precision expected on a industrial robot tool. It uses M3 screws and nuts. The body uses common whiteboard marker (about 20 mm in diameter or less) and requires a spring to ensure that the point of the marker sticks out of the tool, this gives the tool a constant contact force and good drawn paths. The eraser plate uses common pen springs (retractable pens), one on each round slot, use acetone or any strong glue to permanently attach the springs to the eraser plate and then to the body. Add any cloth or foam material to the eraser plate to ensure good cleaning over the board. The springs on the eraser plate give a constant friction force between the surface and the cleaning material. Designed and tested on a IRB-140 ABB Industrial Robot at Universidad Nacional de Colombia - Bogota http://libremechanics.com/

title: Picatinny weight
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
In the wintertime - at least for me - shooting happens indoors either at the expensive shooting range or in the basement. In the basement just with the BB gun so the wife keeps quiet :-)
There is of course a difference in weight and handling and for the weight (I use a small BB handgun with a picatinny rail) I got a "solution".
This picatinny rail attachment has a slider and can be filled with anything - lead pellets make most sense though unless you want to cast a weight that fits right in it.
Attached to the pistol, it gives me a little bit more steady hand and also helps building muzzles (don't laugh, shoot 100 rounds and try to be accurate until the end...) Even though it has the option to put a screw in, at least on my BB gun, it sits tight enough without anything (when printed in ABS).

description.text: Parameters for the boxes are the number of sides, (3 through 12), the length of a side, the height of the box, and the thickness of the walls.  The sides can be decorated with a random placement of trianglar holes on a hexagonal grid.  It is possible to make each box unique.  Five sample boxes and lids are provided.  The OpenSCAD code that generated the boxes and lids is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes: The lids print best standing on an edge.

A single parameter determines the number of random triangular holes in each face of the boxes. It can be zero in which case no decoration occurs. It can be a small positive integer; more holes are created when larger integers are used. The base of the sample hexagonal box was not decorated, parameters for the sides of the box were 1,2,3,4,5, and 6 while the parameter for the lid was 16. Except for the base, parameters for the square box and lid were all greater than or equal to 12 giving faces where most of the possible space is taken
up with triangular holes.

After printing some cool game pieces, I set out to make some 'tree tiles'' for landscaping / boundaries.  Using Tinkercad, I cut some of JAWong's Catan trees and slapped them on one of Dutchmogul's hex tiles.
Be sure to use .1mm layer height when printing these.  They can be scaled up or down to fit your favorite pocket game.  Green on brown dual extrusion also works great. I've included photos of both dual extruded and hand painted tiles for reference.
Files 1 and 2 have different tree arrangements to help randomize your forest.  A half tile is also included for more flexibility.  
Enjoy!

title: Gock Block / Jam Block Handle and Stick Holder for LP Medium

description.text:
July 29 2017
I uploaded a slightly modified version of these models that help reinforce the connection to the handle and should make the stick holder a little stronger. I am a marching band show designer and instructor and these "gock" blocks are what I see most instructors and directors use. I have had one for like 8 years and finally decided to ditch the awkward mounting hardware I was using as a handle for a new 3D printed handle. I also decided to make a stick holder to make sure I don't lose it. The handle has a place to loop a lanyard onto, too. I have been using this for a few hours worth of rehearsal and seems to be holding up well. As far as needed hardware, I just designed this for screws and nuts I had in my scrap hardware box, but I'll give a basic description of what's needed. The hex nut hole is about 12mm on the model, but I used a 11m nut and it fits really well. The screw/bolt just needs to fit through the hole in the gock block and about 1"-2" long. The hole is designed with a countersink. The handle is based on Captain Obvious's GoPro Handle
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:278035 If there's anyone out there that actually prints and uses one of these feel free to let me know how it worked out!

Printer:

MOD-t

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 - .3 mm

Infill:

25% seems to work well.

Notes: If you're unsure of the hardware to use, print the stick holder first and use it as a template. It uses much less filament. If the stick holder's clip is too big or small for your stick, gently heat it with hot water or heat gun and slightly bend them to desired size.
I used Tinkercad for all the modeling and digital calipers for measuring.

author: jonaslorander

title: Butter Robot from Rick and Morty - cut in multiple pieces

description.text:
I cut this model (using MeshMixer) into multiple pieces for easier printing. The butter robot in the photos was printed with a .3mm layer height and scaled uniformly to 5 inches tall. I recommend printing with a .2mm layer height for better resolution. I used 30% support material infill for the robot chassis. 
Since the wheels barely touch the treads, I recommend using a larger nozzle (like a .6mm nozzle if you've got one) and a wider extrusion width if possible.   
Shout out to Leonard Pratte's awesome paint job and hardware additions!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Voxel OX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes: Dimensions: robot chassis:
X: 59.53mm
Y: 73.42mm
Z: 123.03mm tank tread one side:
X: 6.78mm
Y: 69.45mm
Z: 21.83mm I used 30% support material infill for the robot chassis. With 2 layers of upper and lower vertical separation, 1mm horizontal offset from part, an extra inflation distance of 1.5mm, and a max overhang angle of 60 degrees. I used Simplify 3D for slicing, so you might need to tweak the support material settings for different slicing software. If you're using Simplify 3D I recommend customizing your supports. Very carefully remove support material so you don't break the arm off like me and have to reprint.

description.text: This is a collection of part files to build a 3d printed/laser cut/CNC hexapod frame that can be powered with various boards. In my version, I used a servotor32 board from an old Arduino hexapod and I power it with a 12V power supply box.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

40%

Project: Building the Hexapod Objective:
-Assembly and wire a hexapod
-learn how to program moves and or apply an inverse kinematics engine Audiences:
-Anyone with Arduino experience
-High school students who are familiar with robotics
-People familiar with 3d design who can modify the top plate to suit their logic board All of the parts in this model are 3d printed, from the standoff's to the frame. The only hardware required are:
-Control board (I use the Servotor32) Other popular ones are made by Lynxmotion. Mine has the servo controllers and logic board combined, other combinations may require modification to the top plate of the frame only.
-Power supply (can vary on the board)
-Bag of around 100 small servo screws
-18 12g servos (metal teeth recommended) Printed parts:
1x top frame
1x bottom frame
6x legs
6x thighs
6x "bottomlegcombined"
4x standoffs
6x leg pin tests (for the pivots)
6x leg pin nuts (grip leg pins) Assembly is very self-explanatory, look at the images to see how it is put together. Programming:
-This varies on the selected board, but the main part of the project is research
-Research your control board to learn how to use it and program it to suit whatever need you want! Possibilities:
-Connect your control board to a ps3 controller and remote control the hexapod
-Apply a premade (or program your own) inverse kinematics engine to the hexapod to model realistic insect like movements

author: mknize

description.text:
The Pythagoras Tree is a fractal created with the following process: Begin with a square, and then create two duplicates scaled down by sqrt(2) / 2. Position the duplicate squares on top of the original such that the space between the three squares is a right triangle. This process is repeated by applying this process to the original shape and adding the scaled version to the branches.
The OpenSCAD code used to create this model is included, but it should be noted that the STL exported from OpenSCAD is not manifold. The provided STL files were cleaned up with the Microsoft Model Repair Service. The rotated STL is in an orientation more conducive to 3D printing, but I have not yet tried printing this model. I will update this description when I do!

Above is a screenshot of the OpenSCAD source code. I am new to using modules to recursively apply transformations, but if you know a more efficient way to do this kind of recursion to make fractals in OpenSCAD, message me!

title: USB Rechargeable Mini Solder Fume Extractor

description.text:
FULL HOW-TO GUIDE on the ADAFRUIT LEARNING SYSTEM:
https://learn.adafruit.com/usb-rechargeable-mini-solder-fume-extractor A portable solder fume extractor is a popular “maker” project…there are countless guides from Instructables, Make: and elsewhere. Most use two 9 Volt batteries and a voltage regulator inside an Altoids tin. Here we’ll update this classic project with current materials and processes: a lithium-polymer battery, USB charging and a perfectly-fit 3D-printed case. This makes a great companion to the Hakko+Adafruit USB Rechargeable Cordless Soldering Iron project. A single microUSB charging cable keeps all your portable electronics tools topped off!

comments.text: First off, I want to say I loved this project. It was one of my first to complete as I start down my maker path. But, so far I have had lots of problems with this staying in one piece. The back, where the fan goes, shatters on me within 24-48 hours. It is a very snug fit, but the fan always goes in. Come the next morning - or later that day - I see my first stress fracture on the case and the following day the case can be bent away because it's broken in several places.

title: Traxxas EZ Start Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I find one of the most frustrating things companies do is make products that only work with their parts. Yeah I get that it is a good business strategy and all but it still doesn’t change the fact that it is annoying. Anyway I have been into RC for a long time and one company that does this the most is traxxas. I wanted to use one of the EZ start systems on one of my trucks for a remote start system I was installing, this truck was not traxxas which posed some problems. Instead of using the almost universal standard of a 12mm one-way bearing for the starting system they had some sort of oval with 2 flat sides. I was just going to buy one of these on way clutches from traxxas but they decided to change the shaft size from 6mm (standard) to 8mm. This led me to build this inset that adapts to a standard 12mm one-way bearing solving this issue. Haha take that corporate the 21st century has brought the power of manufacturing to the average user. Print at .01mm so it is relatively smooth with 100% fill ( why not its small). It helps to print 2 at once to allow for more cooling between layers. You may need to san a little depending on your printer calibration the part has a very tight fit.

A simple drink bottle holder for my daughters bunk bed.
The holder has an 85mm hole and is 125mm deep. It has two parts, the bottle holder and the mount.
The holder and mount do not have to be glued, but I glued them so if the holder is separated from the mount by my daughter I am not spending any time reassembling them.
The bed it was designed for has a slope on it at the position were the holder would mount, so to enable the hold to be level the mount has a step in it. If the bed you have does not have the same slope or no slope the step can be cut off or removed. 
If the bed you have has an entirely different mount requirement you can design your own mount and attach it to the bottle holder via the dove-tale detail.
Note: No structural design or review was conducted during the designing of this bottle holder other than a brain, eye ball guess. To date (~6 months) this holder has remained in place and has not presented any danger or hazard to any body or anything. That having been said I assume no responsibility for the building or use of this design. Use at your own risk.

author: chev383

description.text: I love my Whisper Amp! I usually either put it in my pocket, or set it on a table while I play. I thought it might be nice to attach it to the guitar strap. This would allow me to connect to it with a very short patch cable, and run the headphone wires behind me. In addition to the printed parts, I used 1" polypro webbing (finished by melting the end over a gas stove burner), and some velcro. I got the 16" of webbing for about $0.40 after a 40% off coupon at one of the big box craft stores. I am so far very happy with the results. I was afraid the eyelets for the webbing would be too thin after sewing on the velcro, but it has not been an issue.

This is the second half of my http://openscad.org gear sets. I couldn't get the top and bottom parts of the double helical to union properly, so I ended up offsetting the bottom piece by 0.1mm :( It skeins and prints fine though. This thing is part of a set:
  • spur gears: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1336
    • UPDATE: I'm printing some gears and noticed a couple mistakes on the openSCAD script: the variable 'orientation' wasn't doing anything and the value 'extrudeInDiam' was in fact being used as radius. They're both fixed now and I uploaded a new version of the script.

The openSCAD file accepts parameters for height, pitch diameter, shaft diameter, double helical, teeth (number of teeth, addendum, dedendum, tooth width, angle, orientation), shape (solid, star, circles), extrude in and out (diameter, height), rome (pitch diameter, gear height, number of teeth, addendum, dedendum, tooth width, rotation).

description.text:
Some time ago, a friend of mine asked me to make her a pair of mind-controlled cat ears, and I said, "Oh sure! I can do that." In my defense, I'd had a bit to drink that night, and didn't think she was serious. She was. (Oh, dear.) On sober reflection, I became curious about whether I could do it. All the pieces seemed to be present:

  • The Neurosky headset had just been featured in Make Magazine.

  • The arduino microcontroller makes doing simple robotics like this relatively easy.

  • The Makerbot and reprap printers make it possible to iteratively design custom hardware, which was going to be really important.
    • So instead of completely and utterly insane, the idea turned out to be merely odd. But doable. Anyway, if you've ever woken up and said to yourself, "I'd like to strap a pair of robotic cat ears to my head, and interface them with my brainwaves," your wish has now come true. Prototype 1 The first prototype is complete. It's imperfect, a bit fiddly, and bulky, but it held up long enough for us to put it on and walk around downtown Boston with it. Here's a video of the first prototype in action. It showcases the ears drooping, standing upright, and wiggling at different levels of mental activity: http://vimeo.com/32018607 Who should make this? Let's be honest, this is a lot of work to do in order to make some kitty ears. The purpose of this thing was to learn how to do it and have fun. And I'm releasing it here because I'm curious what else people could make based on it. Make Something Different I'm very interested to see what can be made with this toolkit beyond cat ears. The servo mounts can be used to attach motors to the MindWave headset, which was a bit of a tricky mechanical problem. Now that that's solved, what else could you do? Some suggestions for things you could make to mount on your head:

  • other ears, like dog or rabbit ears

  • antennae

  • spikes

  • fricking laser beams
    • It's hard to make derivatives of .STL files, so I'll be uploading the Solidworks files for people to tinker with, as soon as I have a chance to clean them up a bit. Special Thanks Many people helped me bring this project to completion. Some tried (vainly) to maintain my sanity. Others helped by listening to me rant like a madman (and didn't back away quickly enough). Some others contributed directly, and I'd like to thank them here. Miriam Byroade designed and sewed the fabric for the ears and the holster holding the electronics. Jeff Cutler contributed significantly to the arduino code, and is single-handedly responsible for the MoveToPosition(); function. Amber Ying dared me to make the ears, modeled them, and has patiently tested three versions of them, all the while waiting for a working set. Thanks again to all of you, and to the others I haven't mentioned. I promise to bother you more as I work on the next prototype.

In the near future I promise to put together a full set of instructions for printing, assembling, programming, tuning, and testing the ears. For now however, here's a very rough overview:

  • Print all the .stl parts

  • Mount the servos and ears on the headset

  • Connect the ears to an arduino and tune the movement and behavior

  • Connect the MindWave headset to the arduino

  • Mount and route the wires and components, and make it wearable
    • Printing the servo horns shouldn't be difficult. I made them with a stock MakerBot Cupcake with a MK6+ Plastruder, using 3mm filament. (The ears, however, can be tricky. I printed them with no extra shells and with support material, on a really really big chunky raft. The ear shells themselves are almost certainly getting a redesign as soon as possible.) I'm still taking assembly pictures, which should help a bit. I've created a github repository for the arduino source code, and will maintain the code there: https://github.com/jdimauro/MindWave-Cat-Ears Roughly speaking, you'll want to hook the servos up to their own 4-AA battery pack, bridge the ground to the arduino, and plug the control lines into pins 3,4,5, and 6. Then you get to tune the "minimum" and "maximum" values for the servos, which will vary depending on exactly how you position them. Once those are set, you get to make the arduino talk to your MindWave headset, which is documented on the NeuroSky website. I have some issues with their documentation, and will supplement it later. But once that's done, you should be able to control the ears by putting the headset on. There will be a big mess of electronics next to you on your bench, though. The final step is to make the whole thing portable. I'm still refining this part of it: the first prototype uses a board with "european-style" screw terminals and a ribbon cable running to a protoboard holding an arduino nano, the MindWave wireless adapter, and some batteries. That's All, Folks These instructions are inadequate and incomplete, but watch this space for updates. I'm happy to answer questions or concerns in the comments.

author: ProtonX

title: Miniature Queen Anne Chair
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a miniature Queen Anne style chair, designed for use in scale models and dollhouses. The files below are provided in 1/2" = 1'-0" scale, also known as 1:24. My design goals were:
Maintain delicate proportions, but balance the need for durability.
Print without support
Good looking resolution, with little cleanup needed This does print at 50% (1/4" scale or 1:48) but is very fragile. I imagine that printing at 200% (1" scale or 1:12, typical dollhouse scale) would require support, and I have not tested it.

I printed this on my Thing-o-matic MK7 with a (well leveled) HBP, using the standard 0026 profile, with print-o-matic set to 30mm/sec federate, 20% infill and a layer height of .3 and no support.  I've been printing them in sets of two, as it seems to take about the same amount of time to print one as it does two.  I printed with an extra large raft, increasing the raft margin to 10mm.  
The "double" file contains small discs underneath the chair legs which help the legs survive a knock or two from the extruder, which seems inevitable in my setup.  I've provided a single chair, without the discs, for the better tuned and more adventurous users out there.
I use a hot knife attachment on my soldering iron to clean up any loops or nubs, and separate the legs from the discs & raft.
If you have recommendations for achieving better print quality, I'm all ears!

comments.text: I printed at 1:12 scale. First print worked ok without support; second time I tried it the print turned to spaghetti when it reached the seat. Also I had to print one chair at a time. But they look great and 1:12 is possible with care. Maybe a printer tuneup would help.
comments.author: cjohnson98

comments.text: if your using a davinci the table can be tightened by slipping a very thin washer between the rod sleeve and the table itself at the back right side where the table attaches to the vertical rods. great job i love queen ann chairs and furniture.

comments.text: I just have to say that the video on youtube about the 3D design ten tips was really helpful to me. I saw on one of your prints that you are using a ThingOMatic (I think). I wanted to ask you how you level the platform. Thanks

comments.text: Glad you found the talk helpful.  The thingomatic was my first printer, though I don't use it much anymore.  I used pairs 3D printed "rosettes" - you can actually see them in one of the photos here.  Better still, get some springs, and only use one rosette on the bottom.

comments.text: I had a few failed prints on the MakerBot Replicator 2 until I set the layer height to 0.27mm, and then it was perfect!

remixed_from.author: oscahie
remixed_from.title: Dual 60mm fan side mount for the XYZ Da Vinci printer

title: Dual 60mm fan side mount - (with back-plate & front cover)

description.text:
So I really liked oscahie's design but the fan on the left right side kept catching on the cables for the x axis. So i redesigned the back to have a smooth plate and used some krazy glue to glue it in place. Then I had some small magnetic balls laying around (i'm sure you could find some on the internet I have no idea where mine came from) and made a front cover that used the screws as magnets.
So one dual fan is intake and one dual fan in exhaust. This works awesome for cooling down the bed after a print to get your part faster, it also works wonders when using ninjaflex. 
The variable resistor I used is a 10K resistor (you could use a much smaller ohm variable resistor) just like oscahie's design but I wanted the knob on the outside so I could adjust it while printing.
For power I tapped into the 12V power supply on the back (same place I get power for my e3d hotend fan).
Anyway works awesome thanks oscahie!

remixed_from.title: Super Compact Pan Tilt Camera Mount

description.text:
So I noticed on the horizontal arm the screw head kept hitting the linkage screw next to it so I made a horizontal arm with an intent for the screw.
I also made the finger a bit longer and added finger tips to aid in picking things up. I also made them a bit easier to print by making the square locking indents threw holes instead of needing supports.
I took AtomKemps super compact pan tilt camera mount and modified it a bit and put it on a pole connected to the horizontal arm. (using it for a wifi rover).
I'm also working on a another servo to attach to the fingers linkage so the fingers can tilt up and down.
More to follow.

title: CTC/FlashForge Creator Umbilical and Filament Guide V2

description.text: Umbilical and filament guides for both frame and print head which keep them vertical and ensure more consistent feed. 4mm OD PTFE filament tubes may be included as part of umbilical for first half as shown in photograph. Leave other half free to facilitate filament loading/unloading. Ensure fan cables are properly located in grooves under head thing before tightening down. Note that cable ties feed through the hole used for rear bolt, so be sure to tighten down before attaching the two cable ties. Note that there are two versions of the head end thing, TallFilamantHolder which has guide tube spacing matching the frame end, and LowerFrictionFilamentHolder which is a bit less form over function and should be used if you have any issues with filament feed; quite frankly it's the one to use if you don't mind the slightly wider tube spacing. Use M3x60mm Cap head stainless bolts to secure thing to extruder head. Existing support bolt may be used at frame end. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1339162 if you have alternate filament guides and just want the umbilical support.

author: Superrei

description.text:
3D printed heart shaped box with red LED, which is simulating heart beat. Electronics consist just of ATTINY45, CR2032 button battery, RED SMD5050 LED, push button, resistor, capacitor and some wires..
I used the original design, but I printed just bottom part of the lid and after that I printed the lid holder separately and put it on the push button. https://youtu.be/UsCT8t6KVLU https://youtu.be/aolZUn9VYpc
